div.salute: My Dear Brother in the Lord
div.p:
Knowing that you take a deep
interest in everything relating to the extension of the RedeemersRedeemer's
kingdom both at home & abroad, and feeling persuaded
that the relationship which has existed between us is still
sometimes remembered both by you and the Church in
Hamilton I have no hestiancy in writing you a short
epistle respecting the dark negros of the world a negro of
which it may truly be said it is the "land of shadow
of death." Darkness more than Egyptian has overspread it
And Satan low has retained in undisturbed possession, his
seat in it, - pert now returned from a journey
of about 700 mile length during which I ^have had ample
opportunities of observing the miserable state of the inhabitants
in the Interior of the continent and really no words can
express their sad conditions. Their state now is generally
wretched in the extreme and their prospects for the future
are as dark as midnight. We visited several tribes, some
of whom had never seen a white man except one on
enterpreneuringentrepreneuring Scotch trader who a few years ago visited
much of the Interior in serach of Ivory & one tribe which
had lived out of the tract of other traders who have since
gone into the country had never beheld a white face so
our just intercourse with them was sufficiently amusing
and then subsequent kindness, good behaviors and
good sense of their chief have quite endeared them to
us, West of the other tribes being accustomed to see traders
surrounded our waggonswagons as soon as we approached their
towns, commencing begging with all their might, a
failure for which generally they Pechanas are note But
here the women fled into their houses & the child
screamed in turns the men with the chief in the centre were
drawn up in line before Fever & waited respectfully until
we had unyoked & approached them after salutations they
panted out to his dignitaries who advanced & formed a semicircle
The chief in the centre of it & myself Mr Edwards & myself with
two of our christianChristian natives who accopmanied us in the middle
thus arranged we sat down on the sand when refreshments
were brought of which the chief tasted & then handed over
to us. We were quite at home with them all in a minute
or two as they knew one of our native Christians, (the
son of an ungodly chief) and he explained our objects --
div.ab:
When you write please attach me at Kuruman CaveCove of RevdReverend DrDoctor Phillip Church Square Cape Town
By the end of next month I hope again to go with the veterans with for the purpose of planting two of our bretherenbrethren
amongst a tribe of countrymen - I shall remain some time with them, kind regards to Mrs M.

div.p:
One of the chiefs having sore eyes I promised him medicine which
pleased him so much he never afterward left my waggonswagons
except for the purpose of bringing me beans, porridge or nul
We then went to the chiefschief's house and in passing through to
Town the women peeped past their gateways but none of them
dared to wait untilluntil we came near, the very dogs stoptstopped me
to bark but fled with precipitation as if they had seen a
lion or tiger, But before we left we had gained itshis confidence
His gospel preached by Mr E. & our people without the least
appearance of fear, and all behaved with decorum both
during sermon & prayer - I feel wicked to say much more
about this tribe but forbear in order that I may have a
little space to speak concerning the great importance of
the churches at home immediately taking possession of these
tribes in the name of the Lord. When men & lands are
discovered by voyagers it is their custom to take possess-
-ion of them in name of their monarch when we can
take possession of these tribes in a far nobler sense
Every church almost might take a tribe under its care
for if we can place two native teachers any of their
towns. they being able to keep school & preach in their
own simple affectionate manner His message of mercy
and theirs I hesitate not to say as much towards th-eir - evange-
-lization will by His Divine blessing be affected in the
first few years as can be expected from the labours
of any two Europeans -- When we preach to amen
people it takes a long time to efface from the native mind
an impression that what we teach is nothing else than
different customs to which we have become attached
"These are just ways of these foreigners" say they but
But when one of themselves tells them of the way of
life then their minds are brought more directly in
contact with the truth and they are not diverted away
from the subject by the peculiar strangeness which
always clings to foreigners in every country
What I cannot ipress your mind with the importance of
having native agents at work amongst these benighted
people so much as I could wish But if you had
beheld with me the vast difference manifested by tribes 24
250 miles Northward and those only 50 ^distant In the same direction
or 80 to the East & East by North, who have again &
again heard the gospel but amongst whom no regular
systematic operations have yet been carved on
you certainly would heartily wish that the influences which
have made the surrounding tribestribe's scorners & bitter opponent
of the gospel might not reach those more distant before the
truth has made some "headway" amongst them, near to us
that is, within 100 or 150 miles north & N: ,E, the people are
visited by traders, Griepas & who have given diseases but
in remedies either for body or mind and many of them
from having lived as this,4 Stations know the truth
but have become gospel hardened. But legend that
they are more free from the contamination of Europeans
more unsophisticated & behave more respectfully to missionary
they appear to me to be somewhat in the same position as
the natives of newly discovered blends in the South Seas
of that we had the to send some of our converts amongst
these people, some ^here are willing to go and the
greater wordly then what Christians ashame
give their money although they give largely, For
£10 is by no means sufficient to support one in this
country, they receive it thankfully as an assistance but
they are still occasionally to go out & hunt, but in this
they are also useful for rewe in hunting when they
arrive at villages collect the people & preach to the
I shall speak freely (but privately) to you & I impore you
to try if you with my Dear friends John & Samuel, cannot
somehow or another collect as much as seculera natives
Missionary as your representative here in the Interior
As the natives say "my heart asks strongly" two
But knowing the circumstances of the church I have
not confidence to write them publiclypublically if you can do anything
more than you are now doing Do think of
Interior of Africa had with John &
As I can; Remember we to this J. & S. & the on. I
knew they have love to the cause of Christ and they will
make an effort to help it on here. If you saw my
heart you would excuse me for wanting so urgently and
what I implore you to attempt if possible, I am not
unwilling to attempt myself. By being hard I fondly hope to
be able to support 1 if not 2 from my salary which is at
present such as is no more than sufficient to keep me
in the rank of a tradesman at home and I am willing
to beat all the fatigue & expense of taking these teachers
to their destination. Each journey amount to about £6
I mention these things implicitly believing that they will not go
a single step beyond your own family work & I mention
I do not think by way of boasting But I feel so anxious for
the object I wanted to anything, if anything more than letting
you knew the real state of the case were necessary
to stit you up & provoke you to love & good works
I know you dont need it but my heard was speaking
the Church here raises annually between £20 & £30 & there is
scarcely any money amongst them, most of them are
really poor, none so as negros food & clothing than
wearers in Hamilton, yesterday 1 paid my driver 18
dollars for as wages for the journey which we had first
concluded & in which he had endured an immense
fatigue, no sooner had he the money in his
